text: A luminous Pacific Island scene — palm trees, hula girls a crescent of golden sand that borders vibrant ocean, illustrated 1950s style. PULLING BACK to reveal a Pacific tapa cloth pattern borde a kitsch lamp-shade. Black Sambuca swirls into a shot glass on a shiny black b JAKE SAWYER, late 20s, handsome and haunted-looking, knoc the shot back and slams the glass down. IN A DARK CORNER OF THE BAR, Jake picks up a payphone receiver. His fingers hover over the buttons, reluctant t dial ... he hangs up. Jake picks up a leather bag from beside his bar stool. As reaches down, we see a long, pale scar on his forearm.

Rain hammers down as a dark Mercedes sedan rolls through Singapore’s streets. INSIDE, Jake watches the lights blur past the rain-streak glass. A CHAUFFEUR drives silently. OUTSIDE, the bustle gives way to a more stately part of t the affluent Holland District.

The Mercedes pulls up outside an old property. The house reeks of both old money and new. Expansive grounds fall a into darkness beyond the haze of rain. Jake steps out of the car. Thunder rolls overhead as he l up at the house.

The Chauffeur shows Jake into a marbled foyer. A staircas sweeps up into darkness. Jake shivers. A figure descends the stairs. MR LIM is silver haired and slight. He looks like he hasn’t slept in weeks. He extend hand.
Edward Lim.
Jake Sawyer. Jake shakes Mr Lim’s hand. As he does, we see that the ba of Jake’s hand is covered with intricate tattoos.
Thank you for coming.
A well-appointed living room, mahogany and leather, pools shadow. Jake sits in an armchair, flipping through a worn looking leather journal. Mr Lim paces, wringing his hands
Have you ever encountered a bad spirit, Mr Sawyer?
(under his breath) Almost every night.
It is eating him from within. So strong ... so hungry. Unseen by Mr Lim, Jake rolls his eyes. He hands Mr Lim th journal. We can’t see what’s on the page.
This is what you need.
(impressed) How did you get this? (CONTINUED)
(grins) Ed, you worry about your karma, let me worry about mine.
It’s powerful?
(laying it on thick) And strictly forbidden. I’m taking a big risk giving this to him. Mr Lim hands Jake an envelope. Jake looks inside.
It is enough? Jake's eyes glint in triumph: it’s more than enough.
Where is he?
Mr Lim leads Jake up a long, shadowy hallway. Jake approa the door as if this creepy setting is all in a day’s work Lim opens the door.

Jake steps into the room. Candles flicker, incense burns. walls and ceiling are scrawled with Chinese symbols. A YOUNG BOY (13) sits up on the bed. He looks flu-ridden miserable. Breath rattles as his scrawny chest rises and falls. Seeing the child, Jake looks taken aback — clearly this wasn’t what he expected. From behind him, the sound of rapid, CRUNCHING FOOTSTEPS. Jake turns —
Footsteps crunch through snow. (CONTINUED)
A slender teenager runs towards a dark house: YOUNG JAKE. Behind him, a dark treeline. Out of breath, he looks back afraid —
Jake blinks. Mr Lim watches him from the doorway.
You never said he was a kid. He looks back at the sick boy.
Have you seen a doctor?
This isn’t something a doctor can cure ... but you can. Can’t you? Jake wrestles with this, then nods.
If that’s the way you want to go.
We must be prepared to do anything for our loved ones. Even if it causes them pain. (to the boy) This is the man I told you about. He’s here to help us. Jake sits down beside the boy, clearly uneasy.
Hey, kid. I’m Jake. What’s your name? The boy watches him, wide-eyed, fearful. JAKE (CONT’D) (smiles) Strong and silent type, huh?
Is this going to hurt? Another flicker of guilt crosses Jake’s face. (CONTINUED)
Your Dad thinks it’s going to help you get better.

What do you think? Jake meets the boy’s eyes, then looks away, unable to lie Jake opens his bag. A TATTOOIST’S NEEDLE is deftly assemb He skims through the notebook: images of hand-drawn symbo flutter past. Jake’s needle BUZZES. The tattoo takes shape under its po an ancient Thai symbol, lines etched with skill and precision. Jake wipes blood and ink from the child’s skin. He glance to see that the boy is sobbing quietly. His father holds boy's wrists tightly, his knuckles white. He whispers desperate assurances to the boy in Malay. Behind the boy’s sobs, a ROAR builds —

Shivering with fear, Young Jake huddles against a cracked grimy mirror in a dark basement corner. Beside him an iro boiler roars and rattles ... TIC-TIC-TIC-TIC ... A DARK FIGURE looms, its reflection fragmented in the mir A BLADE flashes, slices SKIN, BLOOD wells — Young Jake SCREAMS —

The scream seems to reverberate around the tight hallway Jake steps out of the bedroom, bag in hand. He looks back Beyond, Mr Lim kneels at his son’s bedside in prayer. Jak turns away and strides up the hall, his expression grim.
Hey ... EXT. SINGAPORE TATTOO EXPO/JAKE’S BOOTH - DAY 12 The sprawling bustle of a convention, a multi-cultural microcosm of booths, stages, showcases and tents. (CONTINUED)

A banner reads TATTOO EXPO 2007 in both English and Chine Music booms. Jake hesitates, needle hovering over a partially complete tattoo around a skinny forearm. The design is striking, tribal motifs in black ink.
Hey!
Huh? His wiry Singaporean CUSTOMER looks up at him, nervous.
I said, is this for real? Jake slips effortlessly back into salesman mode:

You ever hear of a Dayak tribesman with carpal tunnel syndrome? Jake continues tattooing. Behind them, a sign above Jake’s stall reads MYSTICAL TAT FOR PROTECTION AND WELL-BEING. Posters show ethnic design and their promised effect: GOUT, RHEUMATISM, HEMORRHOIDS more. Ethnic tattooing tools decorate the walls, an attempt to the display some credibility.
Big night last night, huh?
Nothing I can’t handle.
Jake stuffs his tools into his bag. He shoulders it, look to see a figure watching him: MR LIM. If he looked sleep- deprived the night before, he now looks positively zombif
Your tattoo did not work.
(quietly) It was just a tattoo. (CONTINUED)
Then the fault is yours. Evasive, Jake looks around to see who might be listening.

(quietly) Listen, you believe in I Ching, Feng Shui or faery folk, that’s your business ... but next time your kid gets sick, you really want him to get better, take him to a doctor! Jake pushes past Lim and disappears into the crowd. Mr Li stares after Jake, trembling with rage.

Jake glances back over his shoulder as he pushes through crowd. Mr Lim is still following him. Jake slips between booths — Ahead is a large tent. TAP-TAP-TAP! The sound emanates fr darkness. TAP-TAP-TAP! Jake ducks inside.

Jake stands in the shadows of the tent entrance, watching crowd pass by. No sign of Mr Lim. Behind him, the TAP-TAP continues. A young woman, SINA, watches Jake from the shadows of the tent. She’s in her early 20s, beautiful, a red hibiscus flower behind her ear. Her eyes travel to the scar on his arm.
Can I help you? Jake turns to see her. In awe and off-guard, he struggles find his voice:
I don’t know. Maybe.
Sina! (CONTINUED)

Sina disappears into the darkness of the tent, towards th source of the sound. Jake watches after her ... then foll The main area of the tent is bathed in the soft glow of candlelight. Soft Pacific dub plays from an old boom-box. Jake steps forward, captivated ... SEMO (early 20s) lies half-naked amid the other men. An incredible tattoo in progress spreads across his buttocks down his legs: THE PE’A, a traditional Samoan tatau. The tattooist leans over him. ALIPATI’s lean body is coiled l a spring, shining with sweat. Sina sits down beside Semo and begins to massage his temp She whispers in his ear, soothing. Dark ink is poured, thick like blood. A bone tool is dipp Skin is stretched taut. One of the onlookers, PENI, holds Semo’s skin taut for Alipati — TAP-TAP-TAP! Another tool falls and black ink spatters, t is wiped away to reveal the vivid lines of tatau beneath. general sense of calm, of serene concentration. Jake's eyes pick up other details: a single tear runs dow Semo’s cheek. The ragged hitch of his breathing. Alipati leans to whisper in Semo’s ear:

Time out, brutha. Semo moves to sit up, leans on Alipati for support. Their heads touch and they share each other’s breath, bef Semo nods and manages to sit up. Jake watches this exchan of trust, astonished — he’s never seen a tattooing experi shared so powerfully. Sina watches as Jake takes this all in, enjoying the impression the display is making.
(impressed) Jesus. Alipati looks up, notices Jake.
You looking for him, you got the wrong tent. (CONTINUED)

Alipati gets to his feet. His full pe’a wraps around his thighs and torso, dazzling in its intricacy, the spaces between the ink luminous in the golden light. ALIPATI (CONT’D) Flash tats, bro — got something to prove? Jake nods towards Alipati’s tatau.
What about you?
You get the pe’a, you don’t gotta prove nothing to anyone, ever again.
This is from the South Pacific, right?
Samoan tatau, outta Auckland.

New Zealand? Jake looks around. A DISPLAY of ancient tattooing TOOLS, and wood bound with flax, is carefully arranged on a tapa cloth draped over a desk to one side. They look as though they haven’t been used for many years. Jake picks up a bone tool from the display at peers at it The points are needle-sharp. JAKE (CONT’D) Do they have any medicinal value? You know, protection, healing, that kind of thing?
(scoffs) You mean like ‘Tattoos for Protection and Wellbeing’? Jake grins, good-natured but nevertheless defensive.
Hey, a man’s got to make a living. Alipati approaches Jake, his gaze intense. (CONTINUED)
This ain’t just a living. You get the pe’a to honour the spirits of your tupuaga, who wore it before you. You get it to honour your father. And your father’s father.

What if your father isn’t worth honouring? Alipati narrows his eyes, nods, as if Jake has just given away some crucial detail. Sina watches, interested. Jake takes a step back as Alipati leans in close, his voi soft, emphatic:

The pain of the tatau, it changes you. You breathe into it, accept it, learn from it. Only then can you find a way through. Alipati’s hand snaps out and grabs Jake’s wrist, turns it over to reveal the livid scar on Jake’s inner arm. Alipat nods, as though the scar confirms his suspicions about Ja ALIPATI (CONT’D) You know what I’m talking about. You seen pain. Only, you ain’t found a way through yours, eh? These words strike Jake, seem to sink in ... then defensiveness kicks in. He tries to pull away.
I’m just looking for some styles to do.

That ain’t all you’re looking for. (beat) Sometimes it’s right in front of your eyes, brutha. You just gotta open them. Jake yanks his arm from Alipati’s grip, eyes blazing with anger. Alipati smirks and turns away, as if unsurprised b Jake's reaction. Jake turns to leave, fuming. (CONTINUED)
ALIPATI (CONT’D) (his back to Jake) It was a rose. With a barb wire stem. Jake freezes for a moment, eyes wide ... then steps out o the tent.
Outside the tent, Jake looks down — he still holds the bo and wood tool he was looking at before. With a last glance back towards the tent, he stuffs it in his pocket and strides away.

Jake is back in his spot at the bar, a shot of Sambuca in front of him. Behind him, the post-convention crowd is a of leather, ink and pierced flesh under black-light and n Jake seems disconnected from the world, his expression distant as he toys absently with the tool he stole. Despi the crowd, he is alone. A heavily-tattooed middle-aged man leans over.
Lemme guess — tattoo me with that and my dick’1l grow four inches overnight?
You never know. Jake turns away ... to see Mr Lim pushing through the bar towards him. He looks for an exit, but he’s cornered. JAKE (CONT’D) Look, what do you want — a refund?
If you don’t believe, your actions have no power. They can cause ... only pain.
Don’t talk to me about pain. (CONTINUED)
My son died this morning. This hits Jake like a hammer. He looks away, trying to ma sense of this.
He’s ... dead?
Now do you understand what you've done?
(weakly) God, I’m sorry ...

You will be. Jake looks down — The blade of a knife flicks open, catches the light — Jake stumbles back against the bar, crashing into other patrons. Jake scrabbles for purchase ... he falls, bringing the Polynesian lamp from the bar crashing down with him ... P The bulb shatters and the lamp goes dark. His point made, Mr Lim stands over Jake and looks down on him. On the floor, Jake looks wretched, at the end of the line.
Go on, then ... do it. Lim’s anger seems to fade, leaving only pity for Jake.

Perhaps a man who believes in nothing is already dead. Mr Lim pushes away through the crowd. Jake looks up, dazed, to see patrons staring down at him. Among them is the Tattooed Punter — he shakes his head in disgust and turns away. Jake frowns, noticing — (CONTINUED)

BLOOD drips from his clenched fist. He opens it to reveal Samoan tool. Its needle points have bitten deep into his palm. The noise of the bar is pushed into the distance. TAP-TAP ... TAP-TAP-TAP! The sound of the Samoan tattooist at wor Polynesian voices united in song, strangely menacing. We PUSH IN on the lamp lying on its side next to Jake, towards its now dark scene of Pacific kitsch. The sounds tatau in progress intensify ... INT. DREAM — VARIOUS 17 TAP-TAP-TAP! Samoan tattooing tools work dark skin, leavi their dense pattern of ink and blood. A distinctive tapa cloth design. Beyond, flax matting disappears into shadow

JAKE'S NEEDLE etches the last of the Chinese symbol onto Lim’s son. The young boy’s eyes are open, bloodshot, glaz and dilated. Dead. YOUNG JAKE huddles in the shadows. The boiler’s ticking i indistinguishable from the sound of the tattooing tools. dark figure looms.
You’ve brought shame on our house. A KNIFE BLADE glows red-hot against the boiler.

(distant, distorted) You seen pain. Only, you ain’t found a way through yours ... The movement of the tattooing tools becomes frenzied. A f clenches in pain ... blood flows ... TAP-TAP-TAP! The lin of pe’a are black, vivid — graphic patterns wrap around t curve of a body in extreme close up — ALIPATI (0.S.) (CONT’D) (distant, distorted) Sometimes it’s right in front of your eyes, brutha. You just gotta —
Jake opens his eyes. (CONTINUED)

The TAPPING of the tools swirls around him as he sits bol upright on his bed in a shitty, neon-lit hotel room. His chest heaving, Jake looks across to the bedside table, an the tool he stole from the Samoans.

Booths are being dismantled and packed away. Jake appears a run. He reaches the spot where the Samoan tent was and stops, out of breath. The tent is gone. Jake looks down, to the Samoan tool hel his hand. Fading in, the roar of JET ENGINES ...

A plane thunders towards the tarmac, landing gear impacti with a squeal. A fully tattooed Maori warrior looks down from a massive that reads: Haere mai ki te whenua o Aotearoa — Welcome t New Zealand. Jake looks up at the sign, impressed. Behind him, the bus of travellers arriving and departing. Jake heads for a li of waiting taxis.

A TAXI DRIVER holds the boot of the car open for Jake to his bags. A swirling Moko design encircles one of his forearms. Jake pulls a LANGUAGES OF THE SOUTH PACIFIC phrasebook fr the pocket of his bag and looks up a word:
Talofa.
(shakes his head) Kia ora. Jake looks blankly at him.
(grins) I’m Maori. Not Samoan. (CONTINUED)
Jake nods, confused. The driver SLAMS the boot closed —

A car horn BLARES. SUVs and sedans fight for space, along a multicultural pedestrian tide. Jake watches from inside a taxi. A glimpse of Ta Moko her Samoan tattoo design there — every variation on contempor tattooing, worn openly with pride.

SLAM! The door closes behind Jake. He stands in an empty motel-style apartment. A short hallway leads towards the bedroom. Jake puts down his bags. Jake slides open the drawer of the bedside table, grabs t BIBLE that lies inside. He throws it in the trash. Jake shaves. Smart-casual clothes hit the bed. Jake butto his shirt. Jake picks up the Samoan tool from the kitchen benchtop. looks down at it, considering ... then puts the tool ina drawer and heads for the door.
Elaborate signage announces BEDLAM in stylised, manga-sty script. Below, the entrance to what could only be one fuc cool tattoo studio. Jake looks up at the sign.

Extensive mirrors create an illusion of depth. TATTOO ART laugh, joke, dance to Japanese punk. The blacks and greys the decor extend to the tattoos, which seem accomplished soulless, generic McTattoos for trendsetters. Jake looks around, impressed.
Son of a bitch. Jake turns to see CRASH (mid-30s), American, heavily-tatt and dressed in designer cool. (CONTINUED)
You got some serious balls. Jake meets Crash’s glare. The murmur of conversation quel
Come on, Crash ... forgive and forget, huh? One of Crash’s tattooists, CANINE, approaches, concerned.
Crash ...?
(to Canine) My first studio. Apple of my eye. This little fucker steals a design off my wall. Embarrassed silence. Jake returns Crash’s gaze, clearly guilty of this offence.

Tattoos some South Central hip-hop who-the-fuck-is-this-guy, next thing I know they’re jerking each other off over my fucking design in a sidebar on page seventeen of Tattooist Magazine. Guilty again.
Then he trashes my Porsche ... Jake frowns — eh?
... fucks my dog, steals my AmEx and spends up big at Saks Fifth Avenue. (starts to grin) Lingerie department. (beat) My mother’s size. Jake’s grinning now too. Crash opens his arms.
C’mere. Jake hugs Crash. The onlookers laugh and return to work.  26 17.

A TATTOOIST MAGAZINE image of a younger Jake mugging alongside a tattooed black man in a baseball cap and blin Jake and Crash sit on comfortable-looking couches in Cras impeccably-designed designer office, the magazine open on coffee table in front of them. Crash is on a roll.

The Pacific, it’s the heartland of tattooing — the wellspring, the source. The word ‘tattoo’ ... they invented it, the Samoans, the Fijians, those guys. It’s the wellspring — I say that already? And that’s good for my brand value .-».- hell, I just traded in the Boxster for a Bentley. But it don’t make it any of your business.
Why not?

Cause it’s not in your blood. This guy Alipati — he’s hard-core, you know that, right? He ain’t just gonna hand generations of tradition down to some kid from Buttfuck, Minnesota who thinks he’s had some kind of epiphany. Jake looks away, frustrated. CRASH (CONT’D) Anyway, the old Jake wouldn’t have asked — he’d have just stolen the designs and made out like he’d been doing Samoan tattoos his whole life.
(grins) Was the old Jake that much of an asshole?
I kind of liked him. Egocentric. Pissed off. Self-destructive ... (CONTINUED)
Should've been around when he went downhill.
You know, the only thing that sets one tattoo apart from another is the guy doing the work. Skill - that’s what matters. (beat) Come work for me again.
That’s not what I came here for, Crash.
Give me two days a week. I’1l throw in the company car.
Crash —
The Samoans ain’t gonna teach you shit, bet you anything you want.
Can you get me his address or not?
Jake gets into the back of another taxi. A SAMOAN DRIVER behind the wheel.
Kia ora.
Can’t you tell a hori from a coconut, boss?
Huh?
I’m Samoan. We say talofa. Where you going?
Otara. (CONTINUED)
The driver grins as he slams the taxi into gear and pulls into traffic.
Home sweet home.

Jake stares out at the passing landscape. Outside the window, the heart of Auckland’s Pacific Islan community offers sharp contrast to the roar of downtown Auckland. We pass people on the street, booming hip-hop, roaring ca Pylons tower overhead. From the corrugated iron roofs to flowers and Pacific-style clothes, everywhere we look, th landscape seems to burst with the colour of life.

The taxi pulls up at the edge of a car-park behind Otara shopping centre. The wide expanse of concrete is crowded colourful stalls and vendors, bustling with people. The TAXI DRIVER nods towards the market.
In there. Jake follows his gaze, nervous.

Jake heads through the dense throng of the market. He loo around, lost, then glimpses — A red flower. A few metres away, Sina talks to an OLD SAM WOMAN at a fruit stall, the red flower in her hair. Jake watches, mesmerised, as she laughs and hugs the woman, th walks away. Jake follows. Passersby jostle him as he pushes against t flow of the crowd. Jake darts between stalls into another identical row. He spins, trying to get his bearings. The bustling maze of the market closes in on him, trinkets clothes and fruit stalls ...
Lost? (CONTINUED)
Jake turns to see Sina watching him.
I was.
(she points) I think Singapore’s back that way.
Actually, I was looking for you.
For me?
Your friends, I mean ... you and your friends.

Maybe we should go before you buy something you regret. She leads him through the market, a familiar sound floats above the others: TAP-TAP-TAP ... TAP-TAP-TAP! INT/EXT. ALIPATI’S GARAGE - DAY 31 A back corner of the market, where canvas stalls give way the backs of shops and storage areas. In one of them, Alipati works, his back to Jake. Semo, wh saw being worked on in Singapore sits at the head of anot a young man being tattooed, OPETA, muttering encouragemen Peni and the other guys from the expo hang out on folding chairs and mats.
Your girlfriend’s here, cuz. Alipati notices Jake and Sina and sighs.

Every expo, there’s some palagi wants to be down with the brown. He gets to his feet as Jake steps nervously to the entran of the stall, a tattooing tool in his hand. He glares at Sina. She shrugs. (CONTINUED)
Laughter. 21. 31
That stuff I said, I —
You came all the way to Otara to apologise? Those suckers must pay you heaps. Jake looks around nervously.
You said what I was looking for was right in front of me ... I didn’t understand. But I do now, and all that other bullshit, it’s finished. I want something real ... I want you to teach me.
That what you thought I meant?
Ever since Singapore, I’ve been thinking about it ... dreaming about it ...
I told you, tatau is about more than a living. It don’t start here — (holds up the tool, then taps his chest) It starts here.
I know. I’m ready.
It ain’t skills you need, brother. Alipati turns away.
But I’ve come a long way!
Not from what I can see. Jake watches Alipati, helpless. He sighs and turns away. Sina watches as Jake disappears into the market crowd. (CONTINUED)
(to Sina) You should know better, bringing him here.
I don’t know ... there’s something
about him, Ali. others. He’s not like the Alipati looks at her sharply.

You want to go down that road, Sina? Your uncle ain’t gonna like it, that’s for sure ... Sina nods — he’s got that right. ALIPATI (CONT’D) --. and neither do I. Sina meets his gaze ... then runs to catch up with Jake. Alipati watches after her, concerned.
Wait up!
Jake and Sina walk side by side through suburban streets.
Alipati’s old-school, traditional. They say he can see a tatau before he does it. That the spirits tell him what’s supposed to be there. Jake looks down at his scar.
Or what was.
Tatau's his life — he thinks it’s up to him to protect it.
From what?

From guys like you.  33 23. EXT. MR VA’A’S HOUSE - EVENING 33 A weatherboard state house among other weatherboard state houses. A large hibiscus bush dominates the front of the house. Jake follows Sina up the path towards the door. He looks across — Inside the house next-door, an elderly Samoan woman cover mirror with tapa cloth.
What’s she doing?
She's covering the mirror for the night so bad spirits don’t get her.
Are you serious?
I lived with my Grandma for a while in Apia. There was all sorts of things we weren't allowed to do. Whistling inside, brushing your hair or laughing at night.
And you believe all that stuff?
Maybe. I mean, I go to church. But Alipati’s taught me a lot about the old ways.
Best of both worlds, huh?
For now. They arrive at the porch. SINA (CONT’D) Why did you come here, Jake? To learn tatau from Alipati?
I’ve done things I’m not proud of. And meeting you guys ... it felt like — (CONTINUED)
What, fate?
That’s not what I — She takes his hand, runs her fingertips across his scar.
A guy with a scar like this has to believe in something, right? Their eyes meet. Then Jake pulls his arm away.
Talk to Alipati for me?
Jake ...
I don’t want to take it away from him. It’s his art, and I respect that. All I want to do is watch, and learn.
(at last) Okay. Jake grins.

Now if my uncle comes home from church and finds a palagi boy on the doorstep, he’1ll kick me all the way back to Sa. Literally. Sina disappears inside. Jake looks along the side of the house. The back garden l immaculate, lush, wild with banana palms and flowers. A corrugated iron shed is visible, brooding in the darkness Sina reappears. SINA (CONT’D) Give me a couple of days, I’1l talk to him. But come see me at work, okay? Not round here. (CONTINUED)

She hands Jake a piece of paper, then takes the red flowe from her hair and hands it to him, before closing the doo Jake grins, then starts down the path. TAP-TAP-TAP. Jake pauses, listening. TAP-TAP-TAP.

TAP-TAP-TAP. Jake approaches the shed and cups his hand against a dark window. The sound emanates from the darkne inside. The sound of a car pulling up. Headlights sweep across th lawn. Jake looks around — where to run? A car door SLAMS. CRUNCH ... CRUNCH ... CRUNCH ... the he tread of a man coming up the path towards the house. Jake backs slowly around the side of the shed. A MACHETE leans against the shed wall. Jake kicks it over. The blad clatters against the corrugated iron. Jake freezes. A dark shape on the path — a huge man, his head cocked, massive hands hanging by his sides. He strides towards th shed and pushes the door open. MR VA‘A stands in the shed doorway and peers into the darkness. He wears a faitaga and churchgoing jacket, with silver crucifix around his neck. Mere inches away, Jake cowers against the shed wall. Mr Va‘a closes the door behind him and heads into the hou The door SLAMS behind him. Jake sighs with relief. PAT-PAT. PAT. Jake looks down ... droplets of fresh blood the grass. The wound on his palm is bleeding. TAP-TAP-TAP! The tattooing sound again, from inside. Jake peers through the window ... INT. SHED - NIGHT — DREAM 35 The darkness through the shed window becomes a tunnel, di candlelight in the distance. A man lies face-down on flax mats, moaning softly. A silhouette crouches over him, bony hands working tattooin tools: TAP-TAP-TAP! (CONTINUED)

A partially-completed pe’a design on the man’s back ... t long, sharp points of an ulalei, a ceremonial necklace of whale-tooth ... Something’s wrong. The man gasps, his breath a deathly rattle. The song begins to waver and crackle, as though playing off an old record. The tattoo cracks and festers fresh lines split and weep. The ulalei is streaked with b and ink. The recipient turns his head — it’s Jake! The hammering intensifies and he tries to ward off the blows. Mighty CL continue as tattooed skin ruptures ... blood and ink run together ... Jake gasps for breath. Blood blooms ... a red hibiscus ... the blood clouds outw -+. a horribly bloodshot eye, its pupil fixed and dilated Jake tries to pull away from the blows. The images merge shift ... the tattooist, the rose tattoo, Mr Lim’s son’s eyes, the nightmare pe’a in progress, the ink, the ulalei the blood, the hibiscus flower — Jake SCREAMS —
Jake sits up in bed, breathing hard. Lights from the stre dance through the shadows. He opens his hand ... to find Sina’s red hibiscus flower, crushed against dried blood o his palm.
A small bathroom with a large mirror. Behind Jake, a show alcove with a frosted glass door. He bandages his hand, t fills a glass with water.

The first pale rays of dawn creep into the bedroom. A MURMURING UNDERCURRENT of the dream’s cacophony. Jake s on the bed, deep in thought, his gaze fixed on — The red hibiscus, its stem resting in the glass of water, the bedside table. As the dawn creeps towards it, its pet begin to revive.  39 27.

The sound of buzzing needles fills the air. Crash heads towards an empty workspace, the Tattooist Magazine in han Crash tears out the page with Jake on it and tapes it to mirror, then turns to Jake with a smile of triumph.
Crash, take that down ...
There’s the book.
No original designs?

Get to work. He points. Jake looks across to see LUKE, a Singaporean teenager (18), cool but nerdishly so. Nearby, a young Singaporean woman checks out the images o Bedlam’s work. This is VICTORIA (early 20s). She’s attrac and wearing what looks like a conservatively pretty dress Jake approaches Luke.
Hey, I’m Jake. Victoria turns, holds out her hand.
Victoria. Jake is taken aback to see graphic tattoos snaking out fr under her dress.
